newsitem.title: GREECE: ATHLETICS-GALKINA SAVOURS WORLD LONG JUMP TITLE.
newsitem.headline: ATHLETICS-GALKINA SAVOURS WORLD LONG JUMP TITLE.

text.p: Lyudmila Galkina, given up for dead after a serious car crash last October, celebrated her recovery by taking the world women's long jump title on Saturday.
"I'm just happy to be alive and here. I was involved in a serious car crash last October and for a short period the doctors thought I was going to die," the Russian said.
"I certainly never thought I was going to jump again but fortunately I made a much better than expected recovery and started training again in January."
Niki Xanthou took the lead with a third round effort of 6.93 to send the home crowd into ecstasy but Greek hopes of their first gold medal of the championships were dashed just six jumps later.

Galkina produced her winning leap with a personal best and also a year's best of 7.05 metres with her fourth attempt and although Xanthou improved to 6.94 in the same round she fouled her two remaining attempts.
"At least I have finally got a medal." Xanthou said.
Galkina burst into tears after the competition was over and they were still streaming when she spoke to the media later.
"It has been like a dream. And I never expected to be in front of so many photographers and journalists."
Galkina likes Athens so much that she has decided to stay in the Greek capital for another week to celebrate her success.
By contrast, Italy's former champion Fiona May, will be looking for a quick departure after finishing third.
May was booed when she attempted her sixth and final jump when she might have overtaken Xanthou.
"I think it was very unsporting. I was very unhappy at the way I was treated," she said.
